ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course offered an eye-opening introduction to the breadth of current methodoligies in medieval art-historical criticism. The seminar format encouraged critical engagement with the assigned bibliography, and the wide variety of specializations represented aroudn the table profoundly enriched the discussion.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course's greatest strength was its combination of a relatively narrow thematic focus with a broad methodological scope. This created the opportunity for engagement with critical problems from multiple angles. I question the chronological scope, however: while it is a notoriously impossible task to teach the 'Middle Ages,' this class's focus fell rather late by almost any reasonable standards, neglecting the whole period from late antiquity through the turn of the millennium. The single day spent on classical and Byzantine material might have offered some redress, but in fact the thematic discontinuities which that session exposed (and the rather inadequate literature selected for that session) served only to emphasize the major chronological disjuncture.

Disjuncture was also a theme in the selection of topics for each session: by laying emphasis each week on medieval Europe's engagement with a different outside culture, it struck me that opportunities were missed for attempting comparison between cultures, to assess whether the othering of one group served different ends (political, religious, moral) than the othering of another. 

Finally, it was a great shame that we ran out of material to talk about in the final three weeks of term. Either a more rigorous plan for the semester might have been hatched and adhered to, or the chronological scope could have been preemptively broadened, so that the final meetings of the course could have been used productively.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course does provide some exposure to the wide variety of current critical methodologies in the field, and for that it is valuable. Discussion around the seminar table, though, tended to place greater emphasis on that theory than on the interpretation of the evidence. Twin field trips to the Beinecke and the Met Cloisters at the end of term were highlights.

extras.title: EMST 745 01/HSAR 585 01/MDVL 595 01 - Art & Race in Medieval Europe
